Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

Since Angular 4, Angular's versioning scheme is very consistent.

For inconsistency's sake, it would nice to fill the gap of Angular 3 with a `v3.0.0` dist tag as an alias for `next`.
Now, given that this would be confusing with `@angular/router@3.0.0`, it would be more intuitive to figure out a more unique dist tag like `v3.42.0`

### Proposed solution

Tag Angular `next` version as `v3.42.0` which would be for Angular, what Sid is for Debian.
The main advantage of this approach is that there are fewer letters to type.

### Alternatives considered

Do not tat Angular `next` version as `v3.42.0` and close this issue before it gains any momentum.

Issues.Title: [Feature] - Linking library with application in Angular Multi Project Workspace by src path instead of dist/path - for hot reloads
Issues.Body:
### Command

generate

### Description

Currently, when you create a multi-project workspace with a library and application. To view the library changes you have first do `ng build my-lib --watch` and then `ng serve`. This is a bit clunky.
```
$ ng new base-workspace --no-create-application
$ ng g library  my-lib --root libs/my-lib
$ ng g application my-app
```
The problem is in `tsconfig.json` uses the path  to the `dist` folder.

```json
  "compilerOptions": {
    "baseUrl": "./",
    "paths": {
      "my-lib": [
        "dist/my-lib",  <<--------------<<<<
      ]
    },
```





### Describe the solution you'd like

Update `tsconfig.json` file to point to the src path rather than the dist path. This eliminates the need to build the library everytime you make a code change. Especially when you developing & testing locally. All you have to do is `ng serve` and the hot reload should take care of the rest.

```json
  "compilerOptions": {
    "baseUrl": "./",
    "paths": {
      "my-lib": [
        "libs/my-lib/src/public-api",       <<--------------<<<<
      ]
    },
```

### Describe alternatives you've considered

Currently I have to manually update the `tsconfig.json` file. It would be nice if angular cli can take care of this.

Issues.Body:
### Command

add, build, config, doc, e2e, extract-i18n, generate, help, lint, new, run, serve, test, update, version

### Description

Developers who work on new projects while maintaining existing ones often find it unrealistic to install a particular version of Angular CLI globally. Many developers create tools to manage multiple Node.js versions in the same development environment. This approach allows them to use older Node.js versions for maintaining old projects and newer versions for developing new projects. In short, with a Node.js version manager, developers can use any version of Node.js.

I developed a Node.js version manager for my team that has supported us for 8 years.

For 8 years, we have been using Angular as the core framework for Electron rendering processes. Due to my conservative personality, outdated system deployment environments, and the need for V8-bytecode processing for Electron main process code, we have only used Angular versions 12.2.x and older.

Tonight, I started a new project in Windows 10 using my Node.js version manager. After creating a directory, I installed Angular CLI version 15.2.6 using the command `npm i -D @angular/cli`. However, when I tried to create an Angular project using the `npm run ng new ...` command in the same directory, I received an error: `The system cannot find the path specified`. To create a new project using the `ng` command, I had to run the following command:

``` bash
node ./node_modules/.bin/../@angular/cli/bin/ng.js new project-name --commit=false --defaults=true --inline-style=true --package-manager=npm --routing=true --skip-git=true --skip-install=true --strict=true --style=less --view-encapsulation=Emulated --create-application=false --new-project-root=./
```

To execute the ng command in the newly created project (project-name), I had to modify all scripts related to the `ng` command, like this:

``` json
"scripts": {
  "ng": "node ./node_modules/.bin/../@angular/cli/bin/ng.js",
  "start": "npm run ng serve",
  "build": "npm run ng build",
  "watch": "npm run ng build --watch --configuration development",
  "test": "npm run ng test"
}
```

After modifying these scripts, other commands can be executed like this:

``` bash
npm run ng g -- application main --inline-style=true --prefix=chenhuiran --routing=true --skip-install=true --strict=true --style=less --view-encapsulation=Emulated
```

As an important part of the integrated development environment, Angular CLI plays a core role in project development. It would be great if it could be backward compatible during upgrades. 

Nonetheless, this is just a complaint. I understand that you're busy, so I won't disturb you any further.

I hope the above content can be useful to some people.

-   Fix non-default JSON import error with `export {} from` ([#​3070](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3070))

    This release fixes a bug where esbuild incorrectly identified statements of the form `export { default as x } from "y" assert { type: "json" }` as a non-default import. The bug did not affect code of the form `import { default as x } from ...` (only code that used the `export` keyword).

-   Fix a crash with an invalid subpath import ([#​3067](https://togithub.com/evanw/esbuild/issues/3067))

    Previously esbuild could crash when attempting to generate a friendly error message for an invalid [subpath import](https://nodejs.org/api/packages.html#subpath-imports) (i.e. an import starting with `#`). This happened because esbuild originally only supported the `exports` field and the code for that error message was not updated when esbuild later added support for the `imports` field. This crash has been fixed.

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/vitejs/vite/compare/v4.2.2...d6468a3b1fa11f066a0f38515874f71da7b9640e)

Vite 4.3 is out! Read the [announcement blog post here](https://vitejs.dev/blog/announcing-vite4-3)

[![Vite 4.3, It's Fast](https://vitejs.dev/og-image-announcing-vite4-3.png)](https://vitejs.dev/blog/announcing-vite4-3)

In this minor, we focused on improving the dev server performance. The resolve logic got streamlined, improving hot paths and implementing smarter caching for finding `package.json`, TS config files, and resolved URL in general.

You can read a detailed walkthrough of the performance work done in this blog post by one of Vite Contributors: [How we made Vite 4.3 faaaaster 🚀](https://sun0day.github.io/blog/vite/why-vite4\_3-is-faster.html).

This sprint resulted in speed improvements across the board compared to Vite 4.2.

These are the performance improvements as measured by [sapphi-red/performance-compare](https://togithub.com/sapphi-red/performance-compare), which tests an app with 1000 React Components cold and warm dev server startup time as well as HMR times for a root and a leaf component:

| **Vite (babel)**   |  Vite 4.2 | Vite 4.3 | Improvement  |
| :----------------- | --------: | -------: | -----------: |
| **dev cold start** | 17249.0ms | 5132.4ms |      -70.2%  |
| **dev warm start** |  6027.8ms | 4536.1ms |      -24.7%  |
| **Root HMR**       |    46.8ms |   26.7ms |      -42.9%  |
| **Leaf HMR**       |    27.0ms |   12.9ms |      -52.2%  |

| **Vite (swc)**     |  Vite 4.2 | Vite 4.3 | Improvement  |
| :----------------- | --------: | -------: | -----------: |
| **dev cold start** | 13552.5ms | 3201.0ms |      -76.4%  |
| **dev warm start** |  4625.5ms | 2834.4ms |      -38.7%  |
| **Root HMR**       |    30.5ms |   24.0ms |      -21.3%  |
| **Leaf HMR**       |    16.9ms |   10.0ms |      -40.8%  |

You can read more information about the benchmark [here](https://gist.github.com/sapphi-red/25be97327ee64a3c1dce793444afdf6e)

Issues.Title: Update generate schematics to support standalone
Issues.Body:
Updates the various `ng generate` schematics to support standalone projects and the `--standalone` flag. Includes:
* Adding a `--standalone` flag to all the schematics, similar to `ng generate component`, but also inferring if the project is standalone based on its structure. Inferring is necessary, because the CLI utilities for adding an import to the root module will throw an error if a root module doesn't exist.
* Updating some of the authoring utilities not to look for modules if the app is standalone.
* Having the schematics generate a standalone component with the correct `imports`.
* Not adding `imports` and `declarations` to the testing module.
* Not adding `imports` and `declarations` to the root module.
* Using `inject` instead of constructor injection in the generated component. This is unrelated to standalone, but is a best practice.
